March 15, 1992: Fiction
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student seeks to discover the truth about the murder of two Supreme Court
justices.
RISING SUN, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $22.) The death of a woman leads to
an investigation involving the American-Japanese rivalry.
THE ROAD TO OMAHA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $23.95.) A retired
general and a lawyer scheme to take possession of Nebraska.
VOX, by Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $15.) A man and a woman talk on an
"adult party line."
THE ELF QUEEN OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $22.)
The third volume in a series about a fantasy land.
DISNEY'S BEAUTY AND THE BEAST. (Gallery Books/Penguin USA, $6.98.) A
retelling of the classic fairy tale in words and pictures.
BYGONES, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $21.95.) A dinner party reveals family
strains and love.
SCARLETT, by Alexandra Ripley. (Warner, $24.95.) The sequel to "Gone With the
Wind."
HIDEAWAY, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A man miraculously
resuscitated after he has technically died is haunted by visions of evil.
GUARDIAN ANGEL, by Sara Paretsky. (Delacorte, $20.) A private eye probes a
case involving pet dogs and Chicago scandals.
KISS, by Ed McBain. (Morrow, $17.) Two 87th Precinct detectives to the rescue of
a woman.
THE CAT WHO MOVED A MOUNTAIN, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam,
$18.95.) Jim Qwilleran tracks down the murderer of a millionaire developer in
rustic mountain country.
PRIVATE EYES, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $21.50.) The psychologist-
detective Alex Delaware goes to the aid of an actress.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) Verse
and pictures.
OUTERBRIDGE REACH, by Robert Stone. (Ticknor & Fields, $21.95.) A man tries
to relieve the frustrations of his lifetime by participating in a solo sailing race.
March 15, 1992
Non-Fiction
REVOLUTION FROM WITHIN, by Gloria Steinem. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The
reflections of a feminist on the struggle to achieve self-esteem.
DOUBLE CROSS, by Sam Giancana and Chuck Giancana. (Warner, $22.95.)
Two relatives of the late Sam Giancana recall his life in the Mafia and the
influence of the mob around the country.
DEN OF THIEVES, by James B. Stewart. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) How four men
plundered and created havoc on Wall Street.
BACKLASH, by Susan Faludi. (Crown, $24.) A journalist contends that the media
and political groups are staging a war against women's rights.
UNTO THE SONS, by Gay Talese. (Knopf, $25.) A journalist traces his heritage
through three generations, from Italy to Ocean City, N.J.
BROTHER EAGLE, SISTER SKY: A Message From Chief Seattle, illustrated by
Susan Jeffers. (Dial, $14.95.) An environmental warning.
MEMORIES, by Ralph Emery with Tom Carter. (Macmillan, $19.95.) The
autobiography of a country-music broadcaster.
THE TEXAS CONNECTION, by Craig I. Zirbel. (Texas Connection/Ingram,
$21.95.) A Scottsdale, Ariz., attorney argues that Lyndon Johnson was involved in
the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
MOLLY IVINS CAN'T SAY THAT, CAN SHE? by Molly Ivins. (Random House,
$23.) Essays about the current political and cultural scene.
PLAUSIBLE DENIAL, by Mark Lane. (Thunder's Mouth/Publishers Group West,
$22.95.) A lawyer's presentation of the case for believing that the C.I.A. was
involved in the death of John F. Kennedy.
SEIZE THE MOMENT, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The former
President defines the challenges America faces.
ME: Stories of My Life, by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $25.) The actress's
memoirs.
PARLIAMENT OF WHORES, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly,
$19.95.) A humorist's attempt to explain the Federal Government.
TOUJOURS PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The charms of rustic
France.
UH-OH, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $19.) Thoughts on life's commonplaces.
